H0.text: A cave is a landform that may form where a river deposits sediments over a wide area upon entering a larger body of water.

H1.text: Mountain is the landform likely to be formed when a river enters a larger body of water and deposits sediments over a wide area.

H2.text: Delta is a landform that is likely formed at the site where a river enters a larger body of water and deposits sediments over a wide area.

H3.text: Valley is the landform that is likely to be formed at the site of deposition when a river enters a larger body of water and sediments are deposited over a wide area.

A4.text: At the mouth of a river, the change in flow conditions can cause the river to drop any sediment it is carrying, and this sediment deposition can generate a variety of landforms, such as deltas, sand bars, spits, and tie channels.

A5.text: As a result, sediment drops out of the flow and is deposited as alluvium, which builds up to form the river delta.
